head.hi: To the EDITOR of the MORNING CHRONICLE.

div.p:
To prove how circumspect travellers ought to be in
the explanation of hieroglyphic characters found among
half civilised people, I have referred, in my Researches
on the Monuments of the New Continent, page 62,
to a fact observed among the Betjuans of Southern
Africa. A traveller had seen children etching on a
rock certain characters accidentally resembling the let-
ters P and M of the Roman alphabet. This observa-
tion I have attributed to Mr. Trüter, and I have quoted
the work from which it was taken—The Geographical
Ephemerides of Mr. BostuchBertuch. This fact, however,
has exposed me to a severe criticism in the twenty-sixth
number of the Quarterly Review. In the analysis of
Campbell’s Missionary Travels it is affirmed, that no
such circumstance is related in Mr. Trüter’s work, nor
even any allusion of the kind; and after commencing
with these words. “If any credit were due to the au-
thority of Mr. Humboldt,” the article terminates with
the following, “yet this is a fact on which Mr. Hum-
boldt hangs one of his numerous theories.”

I do not pretend that my name is of great authority
concerning facts not examined with my own eye. Few
authors are more sensible of the imperfections of their
own works than I am; but I believe that in what re-
lates to the Betjuanas, the fault is not so great as this
unfriendly critic would imagine. The fact in question,
contained in the Ephemerides of Mr. BostuchBertuch, of May
1807, p. 32. l. 25. is thus related:—“Among the
Betjuanas’ children of ten or twelve years of age, were
occupied in engraving figures upon a rock with a pointed
instrument, some of which so much resembled the M,
H, and P of the Roman alphabet, that travellers might
mistake them for true letters.” This circumstance was
noticed by me not for the purpose of establishing, but
of condemning, theories, and particularly to prove, that
a resemblance of Phœnician characters, with some signs
traced on the rocks of the Orinoco, is merely accidental.
I was only deceived in referring, as authority in this
case, to Mr. Trüter, a name perfectly well known to
me by the excellent Travels of Mr. Barrow. The
observation, however, is that of Dr. Lichtenstein, sent
by General Jansen, in 1803, to the country of the Bet-
juanas, and whose report is inserted in the Ephemerides
of Mr. BostuchBertuch. As Dr. Lichtenstein often compares
his observations with those of Mr. Trüter, it so hap-
pened that I confounded the two travellers who had
visited the same nation and examined the same objects.
